content: <rss xmlns:a10="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom" version="2.0"><channel><title>Impatient Optimists</title><link>http://www.impatientoptimists.org/</link><description>URL filterable feed of blog posts</description><language>en</language><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{D878F227-94C2-4A15-A213-CA127A97C4DB}</guid><link>http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2015/02/Better-Data-to-Reduce-Homelessness</link><a10:author><a10:name>Jess Jorstad, Valerie Pettit, Amanda Thompkins</a10:name></a10:author><title>Better Data to Reduce Homelessness</title><description><div style="text-align: left; "><a href="http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2015/02/Better-Data-to-Reduce-Homelessness"><img src="http://www.impatientoptimists.org/~/media/Blog/Images/BlogPosts/List-Archive-Thumbnail/D/DA-DE/datablogala3d9712f072e42ed86c4e07cea4c656fpng_png_autocropped_lat_autocropped.jpg?w=110" style="border-width: 0px; border-style: solid; margin: 4px;" /></a></div><p>Better data leads to better decision-making across the many organizations that are working together to make homelessness rare and brief.</p></description><pubDate>Fri, 06 Feb 2015 11:19:43 -0800</pubDate><numberOfComments>0</numberOfComments><author>Jess Jorstad, Valerie Pettit, Amanda Thompkins</author><postImage type="rollup">http://www.impatientoptimists.org/~/media/Blog/Images/BlogPosts/List-Archive-Thumbnail/D/DA-DE/datablogala3d9712f072e42ed86c4e07cea4c656fpng_png_autocropped_lat_autocropped.jpg?w=110</postImage><topic>Urban Poverty|Family Homelessness (U.S.)</topic><program>Foundation</program></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{56A53A4F-2AED-4758-A7D4-190D9D7F63ED}</guid><link>http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2013/07/New-treatment-option-saves-women-from-cervical-cancer</link><a10:author><a10:name>Nina Kouassi</a10:name></a10:author><title>New Treatment Option Saves Women From Cervical Cancer</title><description><div style="text-align: left; "><a href="http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2013/07/New-treatment-option-saves-women-from-cervical-cancer"><img src="http://www.impatientoptimists.org/~/media/Blog/Images/BlogPosts/List-Archive-Thumbnail/I/IJ-IO/io-women-in-malawf9f8c08f01b940e1a446da01a3b726ff__autocropped_lat_autocropped.jpg?w=110" style="border-width: 0px; border-style: solid; margin: 4px;" /></a></div><p>Mariam Ciss\ufffd\ufffd is a mother living with HIV in the Ivory Coast, but when she went for a hospital appointment she did not expect the news which caused her to fear for her life.</p></description><pubDate>Mon, 15 Jul 2013 10:00:00 -0700</pubDate><numberOfComments>0</numberOfComments><author>Nina Kouassi</author><postImage type="rollup">http://www.impatientoptimists.org/~/media/Blog/Images/BlogPosts/List-Archive-Thumbnail/I/IJ-IO/io-women-in-malawf9f8c08f01b940e1a446da01a3b726ff__autocropped_lat_autocropped.jpg?w=110</postImage><topic>HIV/AIDS|Health Science &amp; Technology|Urban Poverty</topic><program>Health</program></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{B0B7DF42-69A0-4F4C-92AB-14137D941F5D}</guid><link>http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2013/07/How-HIV-poverty-and-drugs-intertwine-in-Cambodia</link><a10:author><a10:name>Channy Chheng</a10:name></a10:author><title>How HIV, Poverty, and Drugs Intertwine in Cambodia</title><description><div style="text-align: left; "><a href="http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2013/07/How-HIV-poverty-and-drugs-intertwine-in-Cambodia"><img src="http://www.impatientoptimists.org/~/media/Blog/Images/BlogPosts/List-Archive-Thumbnail/I/IJ-IO/io-cambodi7d8ce98c74ff4ba6b2c565207ce54155__autocropped_lat_autocropped.jpg?w=110" style="border-width: 0px; border-style: solid; margin: 4px;" /></a></div><p>Like many other people living with HIV, Hem Sreylyn\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds story is intertwined with poverty and drug addiction. A mother of two children, she was diagnosed with HIV at the age of 26 after she gave birth to her last child.</p></description><pubDate>Thu, 04 Jul 2013 02:39:00 -0700</pubDate><numberOfComments>0</numberOfComments><author>Channy Chheng</author><postImage type="rollup">http://www.impatientoptimists.org/~/media/Blog/Images/BlogPosts/List-Archive-Thumbnail/I/IJ-IO/io-cambodi7d8ce98c74ff4ba6b2c565207ce54155__autocropped_lat_autocropped.jpg?w=110</postImage><topic>HIV/AIDS|Urban Poverty</topic><program>Health</program></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{27961F7A-679B-4A73-9871-D20AE3CFFE71}</guid><link>http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2013/05/How-One-24YearOld-is-Saving-the-Lives-of-Girls-in-Delhi</link><a10:author><a10:name>Jennifer James</a10:name></a10:author><title>How One 24-Year-Old is Saving the Lives of Girls in Delhi</title><description><div style="text-align: left; "><a href="http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2013/05/How-One-24YearOld-is-Saving-the-Lives-of-Girls-in-Delhi"><img src="http://www.impatientoptimists.org/~/media/Blog/Images/BlogPosts/List-Archive-Thumbnail/S/SJ-SO/sonal-kapoor-working-with-one-of-her-students-fc892933ab55434186e7e33f9d7d528e__autocropped_lat_autocropped.jpg?w=110" style="border-width: 0px; border-style: solid; margin: 4px;" /></a></div><p>Kapoor started Protsahan, a small NGO school that educates at-risk girls through the arts. Many of the girls who come from situations of abuse don\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdt talk for months when they enter her school, but the arts help them trust again and open up.</p></description><pubDate>Mon, 03 Jun 2013 08:00:00 -0700</pubDate><numberOfComments>0</numberOfComments><author>Jennifer James</author><postImage type="rollup">http://www.impatientoptimists.org/~/media/Blog/Images/BlogPosts/List-Archive-Thumbnail/S/SJ-SO/sonal-kapoor-working-with-one-of-her-students-fc892933ab55434186e7e33f9d7d528e__autocropped_lat_autocropped.jpg?w=110</postImage><topic>Urban Poverty</topic><program>Poverty</program></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{5AB1175E-D5B0-4813-8DEB-FF8B23D4BAEA}</guid><link>http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2013/04/Thinking-More-Broadly-About-a-Place-to-Call-Home</link><a10:author><a10:name>David Wertheimer</a10:name></a10:author><title>Thinking More Broadly About a Place to Call Home</title><description><div style="text-align: left; "><a href="http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2013/04/Thinking-More-Broadly-About-a-Place-to-Call-Home"><img src="http://www.impatientoptimists.org/~/media/Blog/Images/BlogPosts/List-Archive-Thumbnail/H/HJ-HO/homeless-gir0970613710ea4200919cc81e78e9d1c9png_png_autocropped_lat_autocropped.jpg?w=110" style="border-width: 0px; border-style: solid; margin: 4px;" /></a></div><p>We know that the way to end homelessness is to house everyone. Yet, ensuring everyone has a place to call home requires a housing supply that is affordable to all, regardless of their incomes. The simplicity of this argument seems well suited to a freshman  college logic course. However, the reality is not that simple. </p></description><pubDate>Wed, 10 Apr 2013 04:20:17 -0700</pubDate><numberOfComments>0</numberOfComments><author>David Wertheimer</author><postImage type="rollup">http://www.impatientoptimists.org/~/media/Blog/Images/BlogPosts/List-Archive-Thumbnail/H/HJ-HO/homeless-gir0970613710ea4200919cc81e78e9d1c9png_png_autocropped_lat_autocropped.jpg?w=110</postImage><topic>Pacific Northwest Community|Family Homelessness (U.S.)|Urban Poverty</topic><program>Foundation</program></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{AFCAB411-1518-4064-BFEF-4DA7D60D8E47}</guid><link>http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2013/03/Theres-No-Place-Like-Home</link><a10:author><a10:name>Kollin  Min</a10:name></a10:author><title>The Music of Ending Homelessness</title><description><div style="text-align: left; "><a href="http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2013/03/Theres-No-Place-Like-Home"><img src="http://www.impatientoptimists.org/~/media/Blog/Images/BlogPosts/List-Archive-Thumbnail/L/Other/l477674cc98d196b1744042a2f7840f6f5a53fb__autocropped_lat_autocropped.jpg?w=110" style="border-width: 0px; border-style: solid; margin: 4px;" /></a></div><p>A program officer on our Pacific Northwest Family Homelessness team tells a story about making a difference, and how inspired he was by a random act of kindness.</p></description><pubDate>Tue, 19 Mar 2013 10:00:00 -0700</pubDate><numberOfComments>0</numberOfComments><author>Kollin  Min</author><postImage type="rollup">http://www.impatientoptimists.org/~/media/Blog/Images/BlogPosts/List-Archive-Thumbnail/L/Other/l477674cc98d196b1744042a2f7840f6f5a53fb__autocropped_lat_autocropped.jpg?w=110</postImage><topic>Family Homelessness (U.S.)|Urban Poverty|Pacific Northwest Community</topic><program>Foundation</program></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{D7F4AFCA-917D-4427-B55A-4EF66EF71976}</guid><link>http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2013/01/Progress-and-Challenges-of-Ending-Family-Homelessness</link><a10:author><a10:name>David Wertheimer</a10:name></a10:author><title>Looking Ahead: A Vision for Ending Family Homelessness</title><description><div style="text-align: left; "><a href="http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2013/01/Progress-and-Challenges-of-Ending-Family-Homelessness"><img src="http://www.impatientoptimists.org/~/media/Blog/Other/A/AP-AZ/avatarDavidWertheimer.jpg?w=73" style="border-width: 0px; border-style: solid; margin: 4px;" /></a></div><p>At the Gates Foundation, we\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdre now entering the 14th year of our work in Washington State to reduce family homelessness. That may sound like a long time, but when dealing with a problem as complex and seemingly intractable as family homelessness, time  is required to find and implement changes with the potential to have real impact.</p></description><pubDate>Mon, 28 Jan 2013 09:00:00 -0800</pubDate><numberOfComments>0</numberOfComments><author>David Wertheimer</author><postImage type="author">http://www.impatientoptimists.org/~/media/Blog/Other/A/AP-AZ/avatarDavidWertheimer.jpg?w=73</postImage><topic>Family Homelessness (U.S.)|Pacific Northwest Community|Urban Poverty</topic><program>Foundation</program></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{5D918734-7D14-4018-B446-E225D9287E55}</guid><link>http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2012/12/Building-Community-Philanthropy</link><a10:author><a10:name>Rose Lincoln Hamilton</a10:name></a10:author><title>Building Community Philanthropy</title><description><div style="text-align: left; "><a href="http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2012/12/Building-Community-Philanthropy"><img src="http://www.impatientoptimists.org/~/media/Blog/Other/H/HA-HE/hawthorne-readin05c1eb274f8944f6980f6da7ca2fa1ca__autocropped_lat_autocropped.jpg?w=110" style="border-width: 0px; border-style: solid; margin: 4px;" /></a></div><p>The Bill &amp; Melinda Gates Foundation is expanding our investments in community based philanthropy in the Pacific Northwest. In 2012, a total of 16 community philanthropy partners have been granted funds to support local solutions to reducing intergenerational<br> poverty. </p></description><pubDate>Mon, 10 Dec 2012 04:56:12 -0800</pubDate><numberOfComments>0</numberOfComments><author>Rose Lincoln Hamilton</author><postImage type="rollup">http://www.impatientoptimists.org/~/media/Blog/Other/H/HA-HE/hawthorne-readin05c1eb274f8944f6980f6da7ca2fa1ca__autocropped_lat_autocropped.jpg?w=110</postImage><topic>Pacific Northwest Community|Urban Poverty|Community</topic><program>Poverty</program></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{9CB5B8C4-B993-4B02-A47D-249F0CFFAE6D}</guid><link>http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2012/11/We-Have-the-Power-to-Change-the-Rules</link><a10:author><a10:name>Joe Brewer, Martin Kirk, Adriana Valdez Young</a10:name></a10:author><title>We Have the Power to Change the Rules</title><description><div style="text-align: left; "><a href="http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2012/11/We-Have-the-Power-to-Change-the-Rules"><img src="http://www.impatientoptimists.org/~/media/Blog/Other/W/WJ-WO/woma3e0e1ac8af5449feab4f90d32ceffee2__autocropped_lat_autocropped.jpg?w=110" style="border-width: 0px; border-style: solid; margin: 4px;" /></a></div><p>The rules have created a social and economic system that clearly does not work for the majority of the world\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds people.</p></description><pubDate>Thu, 29 Nov 2012 09:52:00 -0800</pubDate><numberOfComments>0</numberOfComments><author>Joe Brewer, Martin Kirk, Adriana Valdez Young</author><postImage type="rollup">http://www.impatientoptimists.org/~/media/Blog/Other/W/WJ-WO/woma3e0e1ac8af5449feab4f90d32ceffee2__autocropped_lat_autocropped.jpg?w=110</postImage><topic>Urban Poverty|Maternal, Newborn, &amp; Child Health|Agricultural Development</topic><program>Poverty</program></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">{F31D5389-28F8-4AA3-9B44-07AE47BA2B31}</guid><link>http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2012/11/Photo-of-the-Day-Lifting-Women-Out-of-Poverty</link><a10:author><a10:name>Gates Foundation</a10:name></a10:author><title>Photo of the Day: Lifting Women Out of Poverty</title><description><div style="text-align: left; "><a href="http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2012/11/Photo-of-the-Day-Lifting-Women-Out-of-Poverty"><img src="" style="border-width: 0px; border-style: solid; margin: 4px;" /></a></div><p>Photo of the day for November 14, 2012</p></description><pubDate>Wed, 14 Nov 2012 10:52:23 -0800</pubDate><numberOfComments>0</numberOfComments><author>Gates Foundation</author><postImage type="author"></postImage><topic>Urban Poverty</topic><program>Poverty</program></item></channel></rss>
